text: Katoomba, Australia Mount York Claystone is a narrow band of sedimentary rocks occurring in the Sydney Basin in eastern Australia. This stratum is up to 13 metres thick. Mount York Claystone consists of red brown claystones, of fine‐grained and coarsely oolitic, kaolinite clayrocks. Often seen situated above the Burra-Moko Head Sandstone and below the Banks Wall Sandstone in the cliffs of the Blue Mountains. The line of strata appears as a vegetated horizontal strip.Bembrick C. S. and Holland W.N., 1972. Stratigraphy and structure of Grose Sandstone in the Blue Mountains. Quarterly Notes of the Geological Survey of New South Wales. Formed in the Triassic, it is part of the Narrabeen Group of sedimentary rocks and has similarties to the Garie Formation. ==See also== * Sydney Basin * Garie Formation * Bulgo Sandstone * Narrabeen group ==References== Category:Geologic formations of Australia Category:Triassic Australia Category:Shale formations Category:Geology of New South Wales
title: Mount York Claystone
